Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Tell me then, O thou heir of the argument, what did Simonides say, and according to you truly say, about justice?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: He said that the repayment of a debt is just, and in saying so he appears to me to be right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: I should be sorry to doubt the word of such a wise and inspired man, but his meaning, though probably clear to you, is the reverse of clear to me.  For he certainly does not mean, as we were now saying that I ought to return a return a deposit of arms or of anything else to one who asks for it when he is not in his right senses; and yet a deposit cannot be denied to be a debt.

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then when the person who asks me is not in his right mind I am by no means to make the return?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: When Simonides said that the repayment of a debt was justice, he did not mean to include that case?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Certainly not; for he thinks that a friend ought always to do good to a friend and never evil.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: You mean that the return of a deposit of gold which is to the injury of the receiver, if the two parties are friends, is not the repayment of a debt,--that is what you would imagine him to say?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And are enemies also to receive what we owe to them?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: To be sure, he said, they are to receive what we owe them, and an enemy, as I take it, owes to an enemy that which is due or proper to him--that is to say, evil.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Simonides, then, after the manner of poets, would seem to have spoken darkly of the nature of justice; for he really meant to say that justice is the giving to each man what is proper to him, and this he termed a debt.

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: That must have been his meaning, he said.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: By heaven!  I replied; and if we asked him what due or proper thing is given by medicine, and to whom, what answer do you think that he would make to us?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: He would surely reply that medicine gives drugs and meat and drink to human bodies.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And what due or proper thing is given by cookery, and to what?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Seasoning to food.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And what is that which justice gives, and to whom?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: If, Socrates, we are to be guided at all by the analogy of the preceding instances, then justice is the art which gives good to friends and evil to enemies.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: That is his meaning then?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: I think so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And who is best able to do good to his friends and evil to his enemies in time of sickness?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: The physician.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Or when they are on a voyage, amid the perils of the sea?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: The pilot.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And in what sort of actions or with a view to what result is the just man most able to do harm to his enemy and good to his friends?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: In going to war against the one and in making alliances with the other.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: But when a man is well, my dear Polemarchus, there is no need of a physician?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And he who is not on a voyage has no need of a pilot?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then in time of peace justice will be of no use?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: I am very far from thinking so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: You think that justice may be of use in peace as well as in war?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Like husbandry for the acquisition of corn?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Or like shoemaking for the acquisition of shoes,--that is what you mean?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And what similar use or power of acquisition has justice in time of peace?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: In contracts, Socrates, justice is of use.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And by contracts you mean partnerships?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Exactly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: But is the just man or the skilful player a more useful and better partner at a game of draughts?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: The skilful player.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And in the laying of bricks and stones is the just man a more useful or better partner than the builder?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Quite the reverse.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then in what sort of partnership is the just man a better partner than the harp-player, as in playing the harp the harp-player is certainly a better partner than the just man?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: In a money partnership.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Yes, Polemarchus, but surely not in the use of money; for you do not want a just man to be your counsellor the purchase or sale of a horse; a man who is knowing about horses would be better for that, would he not?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And when you want to buy a ship, the shipwright or the pilot would be better?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then what is that joint use of silver or gold in which the just man is to be preferred?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: When you want a deposit to be kept safely.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: You mean when money is not wanted, but allowed to lie?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Precisely.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: That is to say, justice is useful when money is useless?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: That is the inference.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And when you want to keep a pruning-hook safe, then justice is useful to the individual and to the state; but when you want to use it, then the art of the vine-dresser?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Clearly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And when you want to keep a shield or a lyre, and not to use them, you would say that justice is useful; but when you want to use them, then the art of the soldier or of the musician?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And so of all the other things;--justice is useful when they are useless, and useless when they are useful?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: That is the inference.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then justice is not good for much.  But let us consider this further point:  Is not he who can best strike a blow in a boxing match or in any kind of fighting best able to ward off a blow?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And he who is most skilful in preventing or escaping from a disease is best able to create one?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And he is the best guard of a camp who is best able to steal a march upon the enemy?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then he who is a good keeper of anything is also a good thief?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: That, I suppose, is to be inferred.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then if the just man is good at keeping money, he is good at stealing it.

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: That is implied in the argument.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then after all the just man has turned out to be a thief.  And this is a lesson which I suspect you must have learnt out of Homer; for he, speaking of Autolycus, the maternal grandfather of Odysseus, who is a favourite of his, affirms that He was excellent above all men in theft and perjury. And so, you and Homer and Simonides are agreed that justice is an art of theft; to be practised however 'for the good of friends and for the harm of enemies,'--that was what you were saying?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: No, certainly not that, though I do not now know what I did say; but I still stand by the latter words.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Well, there is another question:  By friends and enemies do we mean those who are so really, or only in seeming?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Surely, he said, a man may be expected to love those whom he thinks good, and to hate those whom he thinks evil.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Yes, but do not persons often err about good and evil: many who are not good seem to be so, and conversely?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: That is true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then to them the good will be enemies and the evil will be their friends?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And in that case they will be right in doing good to the evil and evil to the good?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Clearly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: But the good are just and would not do an injustice?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then according to your argument it is just to injure those who do no wrong?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Nay, Socrates; the doctrine is immoral.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then I suppose that we ought to do good to the just and harm to the unjust?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: I like that better.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: But see the consequence:--Many a man who is ignorant of human nature has friends who are bad friends, and in that case he ought to do harm to them; and he has good enemies whom he ought to benefit; but, if so, we shall be saying the very opposite of that which we affirmed to be the meaning of Simonides.

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Very true, he said:  and I think that we had better correct an error into which we seem to have fallen in the use of the words 'friend' and 'enemy.'

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: What was the error, Polemarchus?  I asked.

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: We assumed that he is a friend who seems to be or who is thought good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And how is the error to be corrected?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: We should rather say that he is a friend who is, as well as seems, good; and that he who seems only, and is not good, only seems to be and is not a friend; and of an enemy the same may be said.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: You would argue that the good are our friends and the bad our enemies?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And instead of saying simply as we did at first, that it is just to do good to our friends and harm to our enemies, we should further say: It is just to do good to our friends when they are good and harm to our enemies when they are evil?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Yes, that appears to me to be the truth.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: But ought the just to injure any one at all?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Undoubtedly he ought to injure those who are both wicked and his enemies.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: When horses are injured, are they improved or deteriorated?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: The latter.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Deteriorated, that is to say, in the good qualities of horses, not of dogs?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Yes, of horses.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And dogs are deteriorated in the good qualities of dogs, and not of horses?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Of course.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And will not men who are injured be deteriorated in that which is the proper virtue of man?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And that human virtue is justice?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: To be sure.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then men who are injured are of necessity made unjust?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: That is the result.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: But can the musician by his art make men unmusical?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Or the horseman by his art make them bad horsemen?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Impossible.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And can the just by justice make men unjust, or speaking general can the good by virtue make them bad?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Assuredly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Any more than heat can produce cold?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: It cannot.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Or drought moisture?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Clearly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Nor can the good harm any one?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Impossible.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: And the just is the good?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then to injure a friend or any one else is not the act of a just man, but of the opposite, who is the unjust?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: I think that what you say is quite true, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then if a man says that justice consists in the repayment of debts, and that good is the debt which a man owes to his friends, and evil the debt which he owes to his enemies,--to say this is not wise; for it is not true, if, as has been clearly shown, the injuring of another can be in no case just.

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: I agree with you, said Polemarchus.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Then you and I are prepared to take up arms against any one who attributes such a saying to Simonides or Bias or Pittacus, or any other wise man or seer?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: I am quite ready to do battle at your side, he said.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Shall I tell you whose I believe the saying to be?

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Whose?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: I believe that Periander or Perdiccas or Xerxes or Ismenias the Theban, or some other rich and mighty man, who had a great opinion of his own power, was the first to say that justice is 'doing good to your friends and harm to your enemies.'

Speaker: POLEMARCHUS
Text: Most true, he said.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Text: Yes, I said; but if this definition of justice also breaks down, what other can be offered?
